title: How to Make Easter Cookies

methods.name: Creating Easter Cut Out Sugar Cookies

steps.headline: Beat the butter and sugar until fluffy.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (227 g) of softened butter and 1 ¼ cups (250 g) of sugar to a large bowl. Use a handheld electric mixer to cream the two together on medium until the mixture is light and fluffy. You can use a stand mixer to mix the cookie dough if you prefer. You can also mix the cookie dough by hand, though it will take longer.

steps.headline: Add the eggs one a time.
steps.description: When the butter and sugar mixture is completely blended, mix 3 eggs into the bowl, but add them one at a time. Beat each egg in on medium until it is completely blended before adding the next. If you prefer, you can use egg substitute in place of the eggs.

steps.headline: Beat in the extracts.
steps.description: Once the eggs are combined with the butter and sugar mixture, add 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of vanilla extract and ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of almond extract to the bowl. Mix them in on low until they are fully incorporated. If you aren’t a fan of almond flavoring, you can substitute another ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of vanilla extract or ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of lemon extract.

steps.headline: Mix the flour, baking powder, and salt.
steps.description: Add 3 ½ cups (438 g) of all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon (4 g) of baking powder, and ½ teaspoon (2 g) of salt to a separate bowl. Whisk them together until they are completely blended.

steps.headline: Combine the dry ingredients and creamed mixture.
steps.description: Once all of the dry ingredients are fully mixed, gradually add them to the butter mixture. Mix the dry ingredients in on medium until they are fully incorporated and a soft dough forms. It’s best to add a small amount of the dry ingredients and mix after each addition before adding more.

steps.headline: Cover the dough and chill until it is set.
steps.description: When the dough has formed, cover the bowl with plastic wrap. Place it in the refrigerator and chill it for an hour or until it is easier to handle. If you prefer, you can prepare the dough the day before and chill it overnight. However, let it sit out for 15 to 20 minutes to soften it slightly so it’s easier to roll out.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and grease a cookie sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the cookies, set the temperature to 375 degrees Fahrenheit (190 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully preheat. Next, grease a large cookie sheet with nonstick cooking spray so the cookies won’t stick. If you prefer, you can line the cookie sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat instead of greasing it.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough and cut it with Easter cookie cutters.
steps.description: When the dough is firm, turn it out on a lightly floured surface. Use a rolling pin to roll it out to ¼-inch thickness (6-mm) and use Easter-themed cookie cutters to cut out the cookies. If you don’t have a rolling pin, you can use a wine bottle, thermos, or heavy jar to roll out the dough. Some Easter-themed cookie cutters that you may want to use include egg, bunny, chick, and flower styles.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies until they’re golden brown.
steps.description: After you’ve cut out the cookies, transfer them to the greased cookie sheet. Bake the cookies in the preheated oven for 8 to 10 minutes or until they are a light golden brown.

steps.headline: Blend the confectioners’ sugar, meringue powder, water, and extract together.
steps.description: While the cookies are baking, mix 2 cups (250 g) of confectioners’ sugar, 1 tablespoon (10 g) of meringue powder, ¼ cup (59 ml) of warm water, and ½ teaspoon (2 ½ ml) of almond extract in a medium bowl. Beat the ingredients together on low for 5 minutes, or until a smooth icing forms. You can substitute vanilla extract for the almond extract if you prefer.

steps.headline: Tint the icing with food coloring as desired.
steps.description: If you’d like to color the icing, divide it between small bowls based on how many different colors you’d like. Add several drops of liquid food coloring in your chosen color to each bowl and stir until the icing is tinted. Pastel colors, such a light pink, blue, yellow, green, and purple, work best for Easter cookies. Start with just a drop or two of the food coloring and only add more if you want the color to be darker.

steps.headline: Pipe or spread the icing over the cooled cookies.
steps.description: When the cookies are finished baking, cool them for 15 to 20 minutes on a wire rack. Once they are cool, use a piping bag or small offset spatula to decorate the cookies with the frosting. Allow the cookies to dry for at least 1 to 2 hours before serving. When the icing is still wet, you can also add sprinkles, colored sugar, and other cookie decorations to the cookies. Store any leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature. They should stay fresh for up to a week.

methods.name: Whipping Up Soft and Chewy Easter Candy Cookies

steps.headline: Combine the flour, baking soda, cornstarch, and salt.
steps.description: Add 2 ¼ cups (280 g) of all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon (6 g) of baking soda, 1 ½ teaspoon (4 g) of cornstarch, and ½ teaspoon (2 g) of salt to a large bowl. Whisk the ingredients together until they are fully mixed. You can substitute arrowroot for the cornstarch if you prefer.

steps.headline: Mix the butter and sugars together.
steps.description: Add ¾ cup (170 g) of unsalted butter that’s been melted, ¾ cup (150 g) of light brown sugar, and ½ cup (100 g) of granulated sugar to a separate medium bowl. Whisk the ingredients together until the mixture is fully blended and contains no lumps. If you prefer, you can use a handheld electric mixer to blend the butter and sugars together.

steps.headline: Whisk in the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla.
steps.description: Once the butter and sugars are mixed, add an egg and whisk it into the mixture. Next, mix in the egg yolk and vanilla until they are fully incorporated. You can use egg substitute for the egg if you prefer.

steps.headline: Stir the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients.
steps.description: When the wet ingredients are fully combined, pour them into the flour mixture. Mix well until the wet ingredients are incorporated and a soft dough forms. Be careful not to overmix the cookie dough or you may wind up with tough cookies.

steps.headline: Fold the candy into the batter.
steps.description: After the dough has come together, add 1 cup (170 g) of plain coated chocolate candies in Easter or pastel colors to the bowl. Use a rubber spatula to mix them into the dough so they’re evenly distributed.

steps.headline: Chill the dough for at least two hours.
steps.description: Once you’ve mixed the candy into the cookie dough, cover the bowl with plastic wrap. Place the bowl in the refrigerator and allow the dough to chill for at least 2 hours. You can chill the dough for up to 3 days, so you can prepare it ahead of time and bake the cookies when you’re ready. After chilling the dough, it’s a good idea to let the dough sit for 10 minutes at room temperature before you form the cookies so it’s easier to work with.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line a baking sheet.
steps.description: When you’re ready to bake the cookies, set the oven temperature to 325 degrees Fahrenheit (165 degrees Celsius) and allow it to fully preheat. Next, line a baking sheet with parchment paper to keep the cookies from sticking. You can substitute a silicone baking mat for the parchment paper if you prefer. You can also use nonstick cooking spray to grease the cookie sheet instead of lining it.

steps.headline: Scoop out the dough out and roll into balls.
steps.description: To form the cookies, take approximately 3 tablespoons (62 g) of the dough in a clean hand. Gently roll the dough into a ball and place it on the lined baking sheet. Make sure the cookies are at least 1-inch (2.5-cm) apart on the cookie sheet because they may spread as they bake. If you like, you can add more of the coated chocolate candies to the tops and sides of the balls before you bake the cookies.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies until they’re set.
steps.description: When the cookie sheet is full, place it in the preheated oven. Let the cookies bake for 11 to 12 minutes, or until they are just set. The cookies will look soft and underbaked in the center when you take them out of the oven. They will set up further as they cool.

steps.headline: Cool the cookies completely before serving.
steps.description: After you take the cookies out of the oven, allow them to cool on the cookie sheet for 10 minutes. Next, transfer them to a wire cooling rack to cool completely for another 15 to 20 minutes before serving. Store any uneaten cookies in an airtight container at room temperature. They should stay fresh for up to a week.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and line a cookie sheet.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to bake the cookies, set the temperature to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (175 degrees Celsius) and allow it fully preheat. Next, line a cookie sheet with parchment paper to keep the cookies from sticking. You can substitute a silicone baking mat for the parchment paper if you prefer.

steps.headline: Beat the butter and sugar until light and fluffy.
steps.description: Add 1 cup (227 g) of softened butter and 1 cup (200 g) of sugar to the bowl of a stand mixer. Cream the two together on medium until the mixture is fully blended.

steps.headline: Stir in the eggs and vanilla.
steps.description: When the butter and sugar mixture is blended, add 2 eggs and 4 teaspoon (20 ml) of vanilla to the bowl. Mix them in on medium until the mixture is light and fluffy. You can use egg substitute in place of the eggs if you prefer.

steps.headline: Mix the flour and baking powder.
steps.description: Add 3 ⅔ cups (458 g) of flour and 2 teaspoons (8 g) of baking powder to a separate large bowl. Whisk the two together until they are fully blended.

steps.headline: Combine the wet and dry ingredients to form a dough.
steps.description: After you’ve combined the flour and baking powder, gradually add the dry ingredients to the butter mixture. Mix the dry ingredients in on low until they are just combined and a soft dough forms. Be careful not to overmix the dough or you may wind up with tough cookies.

steps.headline: Knead the dough to smooth it.
steps.description: Once the dough has come together, turn it out on a floured surface. Use your hands to knead the dough for 2 to 3 minutes until it is completely smooth.

steps.headline: Tear off pieces of the dough and roll it into long cords.
steps.description: When you’ve finished kneading the dough, begin breaking off small pieces that are approximately 1 rounded tablespoon (40 g) in size. Next, use clean hands to roll them into long cords. The dough cords should be approximately 6-inches (15-cm) long.

steps.headline: Twist the ends of the dough together.
steps.description: After you’ve rolled the dough into cords, fold the cords in half. Twist the ends of the dough together to create a braided effect and place the cookies on the prepared cookie sheet. You can make other shapes with the dough if you prefer. Figure 8’s, simple twists, and circles are all traditional options.

steps.headline: Whisk the egg and milk together.
steps.description:
Once you’ve shaped all the cookies, add 1 egg and 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of milk to a small bowl. Use a whisk to mix them together to form a light egg wash.
You can substitute water for the milk if you prefer.

steps.headline: Brush the cookies with the egg wash. After you’ve mixed the egg wash, use a pastry brush to lightly brush it over the cookie dough.
steps.description: Focus on the tops of the cookies so they’ll get good color and shine as they bake. If you don’t have a pastry brush, fold a piece of parchment paper into a strip and use it to brush the egg wash over the cookies.

steps.headline: Bake the cookies until they’re golden brown.
steps.description: When you’ve coated all of the cookies with the egg wash, place them in the oven. Allow them to bake for about 10 minutes, or until they are golden brown.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to cool completely before serving.
steps.description: Once the cookies are finished baking, remove them from the oven. Transfer them to a wire cooling rack and let them cool for 20 to 30 minutes before serving. Store any leftover cookies in an airtight container at room temperature. They should stay fresh for up to 3 weeks.

steps.headline: Finished.
